titlestmt.titleproper: Virgil Hoyt McClintock papers, Inclusive: 1911-1952, undated, Bulk: 1945-1951, undated

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Papers Summary
did.unittitle: Virgil Hoyt McClintock papers
did.abstract: The Virgil Hoyt McClintock papers contain case files, memoranda, photographs, scrapbooks, books, and other materials relating to V.H. McClintock’s involvement in the judicial review of NAZI War Crime cases.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: V.H. McClintock, as he was commonly known, was born on 1897 September 16 in Coryell, Texas, to Thomas and Anna Garrett McClintock. Little is known about McClintock’s career before or after his tenure in Germany, except that he practiced law in Texas, including some time in Lubbock. He married his first wife, Calla Walker McClintock, and had one daughter, Anna Sue Caswell, before the start of World War II.

McClintock’s work with the War Crimes section was primarily spent reviewing sentences given to convicted NAZI war criminals during the Dachau Trials. The Dachau Trials were the hearings held before the infamous Nuremberg Trials, and were trials for lesser-known NAZIs. McClintock was primarily assigned to review two types of cases, P.O.W. cases (often known as “flyer” cases), and concentration camp cases. The most famous P.O.W. case McClintock reviewed was known as the Malmedy massacre, when over 70 American prisoners of war were killed during the Battle of the Bulge outside of the Belgian town Malmedy by troops of the German First SS Panzer Division. The trial was one of the most-publicized and most controversial of the war, with over 70 defendants and 43 initial death sentences (none of which were ultimately carried out). McClintock was also involved with reviewing cases from various concentration camps, including Mauthausen, Flossenberg, and Nordhausen. Case files, memoranda, and reference materials relating to all of these cases are included in this collection.

Unfortunately, McClintock’s first wife Calla died in the United States on 1956 December 23. He later married a German woman, Elisabeth Gliemann, before the family returned to Texas in 1961. The couple had three children, Elisabeth Umble, William Hoyt McClintock, and John Carey McClintock. Virgil Hoyt McClintock died in Temple, Texas, on 1974 May 3. His papers are an excellent resource for any researcher interested in studying legal history, the Holocaust, or justice during World War II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Virgil Hoyt McClintock papers contain case files, memoranda, photographs, scrapbooks, books, and other materials relating to V.H. McClintock’s involvement in the judicial review of NAZI War Crime cases. Of particular note are a large number of case files containing evidence pertaining to the prosecution and review of numerous sentences, including those related to crimes perpetrated in the Flossenburg Concentration Camp, Mauthausen Concentration Camp, and the P.O.W. “Flyer” cases including the Malmedy Massacre.

Virgil Hoyt McClintock was an attorney with the War Crimes section of the Army Judge Advocate General’s Office (JAG) in Germany in the years following World War II. As a member of the prosecuting legal team, McClintock was responsible for reviewing the sentences of over 100 convicted war criminals after their initial trials concluded. Files from his time in Germany, filled with evidence, photographs, and legal procedures, comprise this collection.
The naming of a defendant in this collection does not imply guilt.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to this finding aid the Virgil Hoyt McClintock papers contained no collection-level organizational scheme. There were a large number of labeled and numbered folders, and their titles have been preserved when possible. There were also a large number of documents that were not in folders and had no apparent organization.
Currently, the collection is organized into six series: I. Case Files, II. Reference Materials, III. Legal Memoranda, IV. Personal, V. Scrapbooks, and VI. Books.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Virgil Hoyt McClintock papers, Accession #3912, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Adina Johnson. Released on 2014-07-17.

did.unittitle: Case Files

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains case files and legal reviews pertaining to the NAZI war crimes defendants from the Dachau Trials. The case files are organized alphabetically by the defendant’s last name. Case numbers are also included, and should be noted when viewing files of various defendants that were tried in one trial.
